Dating: LATE PERIOD (not before); 26TH DYNASTY; LATE PERIOD (not after)
Name: Apis Stela
Description: This small votive monument is part of the category of Apis stelae found at the Serapeum. Situated in the necropolis of Saqqara, this place of pilgrimage shelters the tombs of the sacred bulls. The stela has been offered by a certain Harsiesis, who fulfilled priestly duties at Sais and Buto, two towns in the Delta. In the main register, we see the priest kneeling in adoration before the Apis bull. The scene takes place beneath a winged disk, itself surmounted by the sign of the sky. The text, written in five horizontal lines, is limited to the names, titles and filiation of the owner.
